news_summary: Today’s technology news highlights groundbreaking advancements in AI integration for public services, innovative breakthroughs in plant-based food, significant progress in custom genetic sequencing, and impressive achievements in mathematical AI competitions.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité technologique d'aujourd'hui met en lumière des avancées révolutionnaires dans l'intégration de l'IA pour les services publics, des percées innovantes dans l'alimentation à base de plantes, des progrès significatifs dans le séquençage génétique personnalisé et des réalisations impressionnantes dans les concours d'IA mathématique.
news_summary_es: Las noticias tecnológicas de hoy destacan avances revolucionarios en la integración de la IA para los servicios públicos, avances innovadores en la alimentación a base de plantas, progresos significativos en la secuenciación genética personalizada y logros impresionantes en competiciones matemáticas de IA.

articles.title: OpenAI and UK sign deal to use AI in public services
articles.summary: The US tech firm behind ChatGPT say it will work with the UK government to 'deliver prosperity for all'.
articles.content:
OpenAI and UK sign deal to use AI in public services

17 hours ago Share Save Mitchell Labiak & Imran Rahman-Jones Business & technology reporters Share Save

Getty Images

OpenAI, the firm behind ChatGPT, has signed a deal to use artificial intelligence (AI) to increase productivity in the UK's public services, the government has announced. The agreement signed by the firm and the science department could give OpenAI access to government data and see its software used in education, defence, security, and the justice system. Technology Secretary Peter Kyle said that "AI will be fundamental in driving change" in the UK and "driving economic growth". But digital privacy campaigners said the partnership showed "this government's credulous approach to big tech's increasingly dodgy sales pitch".

The agreement says the UK and OpenAI may develop an "information sharing programme" and will "develop safeguards that protect the public and uphold democratic values". It also says they will explore investment in AI infrastructure, which usually involves building or expanding data centres - large banks of computer servers which power AI. And OpenAI will expand its London office, which it says currently employs more than 100 people. The commitment is a statement of intent, rather than a legally-binding deal, which sets out the goals of a partnership between the UK government and OpenAI. OpenAI chief executive Sam Altman said the plan would "deliver prosperity for all". The collaboration could potentially free up "highly skilled public servants to focus on the difficult one-in-a-million situations that AI might struggle to address," said Dr Gordon Fletcher, associate dean for research and innovation at the University of Salford. But he said the challenge was whether it could "really be done transparently and ethically, with minimal data drawn from the public". Digital rights campaign group Foxglove called the agreement "hopelessly vague". Co-executive Director Martha Dark said the "treasure trove of public data" the government holds "would be of enormous commercial value to OpenAI in helping to train the next incarnation of ChatGPT". "Peter Kyle seems bizarrely determined to put the big tech fox in charge of the henhouse when it comes to UK sovereignty," she said.
articles.reasoning: The collaboration between OpenAI and the UK government to use AI in public services aims to improve prosperity for all, indicating a positive technological advancement with potential societal benefits.
articles.personality_title: OpenAI partners with UK to boost public services with AI
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
OpenAI, the company behind the popular AI tool ChatGPT, has teamed up with the UK government. They want to use artificial intelligence, or AI, to make public services work better and faster.

**What happened**
The UK government and OpenAI signed an agreement allowing OpenAI to access some government data. This will help OpenAI create AI solutions that can be used in areas like education, defense, and security.

**Impact**
By using AI, public services can become more efficient and easier for people to use. For example, AI can help teachers by providing smart tools for learning or assist officials in making quicker, smarter decisions. This partnership aims to bring benefits to everyone in the UK.

**What's next step**
Next, OpenAI and the UK government will work together to build and test AI tools tailored for public needs. They will focus on ensuring the technology is safe, trustworthy, and truly helpful for citizens.

**One-sentence takeaway**
OpenAI and the UK government are joining forces to use AI in public services, aiming to improve everyone's daily lives with smarter, faster support.
articles.personality_title_fr: OpenAI s'associe au Royaume-Uni pour améliorer les services publics grâce à l'IA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
OpenAI, la société derrière l'outil d'IA populaire ChatGPT, s'est associée au gouvernement britannique. Ils veulent utiliser l'intelligence artificielle (IA) pour rendre les services publics plus efficaces et rapides.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Le gouvernement du Royaume-Uni et OpenAI ont signé un accord permettant à OpenAI d'accéder à certaines données gouvernementales. Cela aidera OpenAI à créer des solutions d'IA pour l'éducation, la défense et la sécurité.

**Impact**
Grâce à l'IA, les services publics peuvent devenir plus efficaces et plus simples à utiliser. Par exemple, l'IA peut aider les enseignants avec des outils intelligents ou aider les responsables à prendre des décisions plus rapides et meilleures. Ce partenariat vise à bénéficier à tous au Royaume-Uni.

**Prochaine étape**
Ensuite, OpenAI et le gouvernement britannique travailleront ensemble pour développer et tester des outils d'IA adaptés aux besoins publics. Ils s'assureront que cette technologie soit sûre, fiable et vraiment utile pour les citoyens.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
OpenAI et le gouvernement britannique unissent leurs forces pour utiliser l'IA dans les services publics, afin d'améliorer la vie quotidienne de tous grâce à un soutien plus intelligent et rapide.
articles.personality_title_es: OpenAI se asocia con el Reino Unido para mejorar los servicios públicos con IA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
OpenAI, la empresa detrás de la popular herramienta de IA ChatGPT, se ha asociado con el gobierno del Reino Unido. Quieren usar la inteligencia artificial (IA) para que los servicios públicos funcionen mejor y más rápido.

**Qué pasó**
El gobierno del Reino Unido y OpenAI firmaron un acuerdo que permite a OpenAI acceder a algunos datos gubernamentales. Esto ayudará a OpenAI a crear soluciones de IA para áreas como educación, defensa y seguridad.

**Impacto**
Al usar IA, los servicios públicos pueden volverse más eficientes y fáciles de usar. Por ejemplo, la IA puede ayudar a los maestros con herramientas inteligentes o ayudar a los funcionarios a tomar decisiones más rápidas y mejores. Esta colaboración busca beneficiar a todos en el Reino Unido.

**Próximo paso**
Luego, OpenAI y el gobierno del Reino Unido trabajarán juntos para construir y probar herramientas de IA hechas a la medida de las necesidades públicas. Se enfocarán en garantizar que la tecnología sea segura, confiable y realmente útil para los ciudadanos.

**Conclusión en una frase**
OpenAI y el gobierno del Reino Unido unen fuerzas para usar la IA en los servicios públicos, con el objetivo de mejorar la vida diaria de todos con un apoyo más inteligente y rápido.

articles.title: This oat discovery could change your breakfast—and the future of plant-based food
articles.summary: Scientists in Australia have uncovered the biological triggers behind oil production in oats, a discovery that could revolutionize how oats are processed and marketed. By using advanced imaging and molecular techniques, researchers identified key enzymes that drive oil synthesis in oat grains. This opens the door to developing low-oil oat varieties that are easier to mill and better suited for high-demand markets like plant-based foods and oat flour.
articles.content:
New University of South Australia research is providing evidence of biological triggers of oil production in oats, a discovery that will help processing and potentially drive further demand for Australian-grown oats.

While Australia is the world's second-largest exporter of oats, high oil content in oat grains creates challenges during milling, reducing processing efficiency and limiting product innovation - particularly in high-demand sectors like oat flour and plant-based proteins.

Researchers from the University of South Australia, the South Australian Research and Development Institute (SARDI), and the University of Adelaide are collaborating on research designed to better understand the biological processes responsible for oil synthesis in oat grains.

In this study, two contemporary varieties of oats were examined using spatial imaging techniques to track oil build-up during grain development. Researchers then applied 'omics' technologies - lipidomics and proteomics - to analyse lipid and protein expression, which provided key insights into the biological mechanisms involved in the actual formation of the grain, including those relating to oil synthesis.

The UniSA findings have provided further evidence of the mechanisms that underlie the amount of oil in an oat grain. These findings will help to guide future breeding efforts for naturally lower-oil oat varieties, improving milling yields and creating new value-added opportunities across the oat supply chain.

UniSA PhD candidate, Darren Lau, says that current oil removal methods are inefficient and that low-oil breeding programs will aid industry growth.

"While oil can be removed from partially milled oat flakes - using supercritical carbon dioxide prior to further milling - this approach is laborious and expensive," he says.

"Breeding low-oil oat varieties is a cost-effective approach but requires further understanding of oil production in oats. This is where our research is critical.

"Our analysis has identified several key enzymes that are involved in oil synthesis which could be genetically manipulated to lower oil content of oat grains.

"Reducing oil content could also unlock new opportunities in sectors like oat flour and alternative proteins, which could significantly strengthen Australia's position in the market."

The economic potential of these opportunities is reflected in the quantity of oats exported globally. For example, in 2022 twenty-six million metric tonnes of oats were produced worldwide, ranking them seventh among cereals in production quantity.

Lowering oil content in oat grains will enhance processing and product versatility, positioning them alongside traditional cereal staples like barley, maize, wheat, and rice, and further driving industry growth.

The UniSA findings are being used by the Grains Research and Development Corporation (GRDC) oat grain quality consortium to improve suitability for milling and food/beverage ingredient development. Additional research is continuing within the consortium that will build on the study's findings to further inform breeding efforts aimed at reducing oil content in oats.

"The consortia are currently working on a larger and more diverse oat cohort to further investigate molecular markers and nutrient partitioning of oil in oats," Lau says.

"The consortia are also investigating one of the key enzymes validated in this study to determine whether manipulating or removing it can lower oil content, and how that affects the growth of the plant."

SARDI Project Lead Dr Janine Croser, says the study's findings provide further evidence of key pathways involved in oat oil biosynthesis.

"This research provides important insights into the biological mechanisms underlying varietal differences of oil production in developing oat grains," Dr Croser says.

"We expect that the development of low-oil lines will improve efficiencies in the flour milling process and potentially lead to novel uses for oats.

"With demand for plant-based foods on the rise, we anticipate the oat grain quality consortium research will help put Australia at the forefront of oat innovation - supporting growers, processors, and exporters alike."

The full paper, Proteomic and lipidomic analyses reveal novel molecular insights into oat (Avena sativa L.) lipid regulation and crosstalk with starch synthesis during grain development, is available online.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a scientific breakthrough in understanding oil production in oats, which has the potential to improve plant-based food production and processing. This advancement could benefit consumers and the food industry by enabling better oat varieties suited for high-demand markets, representing a positive technological and agricultural development.
articles.personality_title: New oat discovery could transform breakfast and plant-based foods
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists in Australia have been studying oats, one of the world’s favorite grains, to understand why some oats have higher oil content. This oil can make processing the oats harder, especially for popular products like oat flour and plant-based foods.

**What happened**
Researchers at the University of South Australia used special imaging and molecular tools to find the enzymes that control oil production in oat grains. Enzymes are tiny helpers in plants that drive chemical reactions. Finding these triggers means scientists can now work on creating oat varieties with less oil.

**Impact**
Lower-oil oats are easier to mill and process, which means food makers can produce oat flour and plant-based proteins more efficiently. This could lead to more affordable, innovative oat products on the market and help meet the growing demand for plant-based foods.

**What’s next step**
The next goal is to develop and grow these low-oil oat varieties in Australia. This will allow oat growers and food companies to benefit from improved oats that suit current food trends and processing needs.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Understanding how oats make oil opens the door to better oat products that are good for both producers and consumers.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle découverte sur l’avoine pourrait transformer le petit-déjeuner et les aliments à base de plantes
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des scientifiques australiens ont étudié l'avoine, une des céréales les plus appréciées, pour comprendre pourquoi certaines avoines contiennent plus d'huile. Cette huile complique la transformation de l'avoine, surtout pour des produits populaires comme la farine d'avoine et les aliments à base de plantes.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs de l'Université d'Australie du Sud ont utilisé des techniques avancées d'imagerie et moléculaires pour identifier les enzymes qui contrôlent la production d'huile dans les grains d'avoine. Les enzymes sont de petites aides qui déclenchent des réactions chimiques dans les plantes. Cette découverte permet maintenant de créer des variétés d'avoine avec moins d'huile.

**Impact**
Les avoines à faible teneur en huile sont plus faciles à moudre et à transformer, ce qui permet aux fabricants de produire plus efficacement de la farine d'avoine et des protéines végétales. Cela pourrait rendre les produits à base d'avoine plus abordables et innovants, répondant ainsi à une demande croissante.

**Prochaine étape**
L'objectif suivant est de développer et cultiver ces variétés d'avoine à faible teneur en huile en Australie. Cela aidera les agriculteurs et les entreprises alimentaires à profiter d'avoines adaptées aux tendances et aux besoins actuels.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Comprendre comment l'avoine produit de l'huile ouvre la voie à de meilleurs produits d'avoine avantageux pour producteurs et consommateurs.
articles.personality_title_es: Un nuevo descubrimiento sobre la avena podría transformar el desayuno y los alimentos de origen vegetal
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Científicos en Australia han estado estudiando la avena, uno de los granos más populares, para entender por qué algunas tienen más contenido de aceite. Este aceite dificulta el procesamiento de la avena, especialmente para productos como la harina de avena y alimentos de origen vegetal.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de la Universidad de Australia del Sur usaron técnicas avanzadas de imagen y moleculares para identificar las enzimas que controlan la producción de aceite en los granos de avena. Las enzimas son pequeñas ayudantes que impulsan reacciones químicas en las plantas. Esto abre la posibilidad de crear variedades de avena con menos aceite.

**Impacto**
La avena con menos aceite es más fácil de moler y procesar, lo que permite a las empresas producir harina de avena y proteínas vegetales más eficientemente. Esto podría generar productos de avena más asequibles e innovadores, satisfaciendo la creciente demanda.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente objetivo es desarrollar y cultivar estas variedades de avena baja en aceite en Australia. Esto beneficiará a agricultores y empresas alimentarias con avena adaptada a las tendencias y necesidades actuales.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Comprender cómo la avena produce aceite abre la puerta a mejores productos de avena que benefician a productores y consumidores.

articles.title: Made-to-order DNA goes big: new tech doubles size of custom genetic sequences
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 22 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02261-yEnzyme-based techniques and refinements in organic chemistry ease the generation of extended DNA sequences.
articles.content:
Synthetic biology is poised to tackle a range of challenges, from cleaning up pollutants with designer bacteria to the creation of bespoke gene therapies. But the transition from the laboratory to commercial use will require advances in DNA-synthesis technology.

For decades, the only way to make industrial volumes of custom DNA has been phosphoramidite synthesis, an organic-chemistry process that can construct nucleic acids up to 350 nucleotides or so in length. To produce longer fragments, DNA manufacturers build thousands of oligonucleotides, or oligos, in parallel, and then assemble them. This technique can pump out large volumes of DNA at low cost, but it struggles with sequences that are highly repetitive or complex.

The race for enzymatic DNA synthesis heats up

Now, advances in both enzymatic and chemical synthesis are clearing those hurdles.

Enzymatic synthesis is inspired by the method that living cells use to replicate DNA. Usually, cells copy DNA from a template rather than creating it from scratch. But that works only if the template exists, which is not the case for the custom DNAs that synthetic biologists need. An enzyme called terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) can join nucleotides together without a template, and several companies have begun commercializing enzymatic methods that exploit it.

DNA Script, based in Paris, couples TdT with chemically modified nucleotides that prevent elongation by more than one monomer at a time. After each base is added, the protective cap is removed and washed away, another base is added and the cycle repeats. Ansa Biotechnologies takes a similar approach, but rather than using a blocking group to restrict elongation, the company, in Emeryville, California, tethers the base to TdT so that the enzyme stays bound to the growing oligo. A second enzyme cleaves the linker after elongation, allowing the cycle to continue.

Thomas Ybert, chief scientific officer at DNA Script in Paris.Credit: ERIC PIERMONT/AFP via Getty

According to Daniel Lin-Arlow, Ansa’s chief scientific officer, the approach can handle sequences with highly complex secondary structures, including repeats, hairpins or high guanine–cytosine content, which are otherwise difficult to produce. In August 2024, the company launched its first commercial product, a 600-base custom service, which can be assembled into constructs of up to 5 kilobases. “We found a lot of interest from people who were working on non-coding sequences, like promoters,” Lin-Arlow says, which cannot be changed to make them easier to manufacture. And the technology continues to advance: early-access customers can now request DNAs as long as 750 bases, and clonal assemblies up to 50 kbp in length.

Enzymatic synthesis is also making benchtop DNA synthesizers more accessible. Phosphoramidite-based DNA synthesizers require specialized training and infrastructure to safely handle toxic organic reagents and waste. By contrast, enzymatic synthesizers require only basic liquid-handling skills. In 2023, DNA Script began selling its SYNTAX system, a device that researchers can use to synthesize 96 oligos in parallel, with up to about 120 nucleotides per oligo, per day. “It’s as easy to use as your office printer,” says Thomas Ybert, the firm’s chief scientific officer.

Chemical improvements

New organic-chemistry methods are also emerging to tackle long-DNA synthesis.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a scientific and technological breakthrough in DNA synthesis, which can have broad implications for medicine, research, and biotechnology. Such advances are generally seen as positive because they enable new possibilities for health and science.
articles.personality_title: New DNA technology doubles the size of custom genetic sequences
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Synthetic biology is a growing field that uses specially designed DNA to solve problems like pollution and develop personalized medical treatments. However, creating long strands of custom DNA has been limited by existing technology.

**What happened**
Scientists have developed a new method using enzymes and improved chemistry to create longer DNA sequences than ever before. This new technique can produce DNA strands twice as long as the previous method, which was limited to about 350 building blocks called nucleotides.

**Impact**
This breakthrough makes it easier and faster to produce large DNA sequences for research and medicine. It could help design better gene therapies and environmental solutions by giving scientists more flexibility and precision in creating DNA.

**What's next step**
Researchers will work on scaling up this technology for widespread commercial use. They aim to make it reliable and cost-effective so that various industries can benefit from longer, custom-made DNA.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A new enzyme-based DNA-making method doubles the length of custom sequences, unlocking more possibilities in medicine and science.
articles.personality_title_fr: Nouvelle technologie d’ADN double la taille des séquences génétiques personnalisées
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La biologie synthétique utilise de l’ADN spécialement conçu pour résoudre des problèmes comme la pollution et créer des traitements médicaux personnalisés. Pourtant, la création de longues séquences d’ADN personnalisées était limitée par la technologie actuelle.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des scientifiques ont mis au point une nouvelle méthode utilisant des enzymes et une chimie améliorée pour fabriquer des séquences d’ADN plus longues que jamais. Cette technique peut produire des brins d’ADN deux fois plus longs que l’ancienne méthode, qui était limitée à environ 350 unités appelées nucléotides.

**Impact**
Cette avancée facilite et accélère la production de grandes séquences d’ADN pour la recherche et la médecine. Elle pourrait aider à concevoir de meilleurs traitements géniques et des solutions environnementales en offrant plus de précision aux scientifiques.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont travailler à étendre cette technologie pour une utilisation commerciale à grande échelle, en la rendant fiable et abordable pour divers secteurs.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Une nouvelle méthode enzymatique double la longueur des séquences d’ADN personnalisées, ouvrant plus de possibilités en médecine et en science.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva tecnología de ADN duplica el tamaño de las secuencias genéticas personalizadas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La biología sintética usa ADN diseñado para resolver problemas como la contaminación y crear tratamientos médicos personalizados. Sin embargo, la fabricación de largas secuencias de ADN personalizadas estaba limitada por la tecnología existente.

**Qué pasó**
Científicos desarrollaron un nuevo método usando enzimas y química mejorada para crear secuencias de ADN más largas que nunca. Esta técnica puede producir hebras de ADN el doble de largas que el método anterior, que estaba limitado a unos 350 nucleótidos.

**Impacto**
Este avance facilita y acelera la producción de secuencias largas de ADN para investigación y medicina. Podría ayudar a diseñar mejores terapias génicas y soluciones ambientales, dando a los científicos más precisión y flexibilidad.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores trabajarán para ampliar esta tecnología para uso comercial, haciéndola confiable y económica para que varias industrias puedan beneficiarse.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Un nuevo método basado en enzimas duplica la longitud de las secuencias de ADN personalizadas, abriendo más posibilidades en medicina y ciencia.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of an intricate, glowing double helix made of gently interlocking puzzle pieces being carefully assembled by delicate, translucent mechanical hands in a softly lit laboratory setting, with small, stylized enzyme-like creatures guiding and connecting the pieces, all rendered in natural, simple colors against a calm, neutral background.

articles.title: DeepMind and OpenAI claim gold in International Mathematical Olympiad
articles.summary: Two AI models have achieved gold medal standard for the first time in a prestigious competition for young mathematicians – and their developers claim these AIs could soon crack tough scientific problems
articles.content:
Two AI models have achieved gold medal standard for the first time in a prestigious competition for young mathematicians – and their developers claim these AIs could soon crack tough scientific problems

AIs are getting better at maths problems Andresr/ Getty Images

Experimental AI models from Google DeepMind and OpenAI have achieved a gold-level performance in the International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) for the first time.

The companies are hailing the moment as an important milestone for AIs that might one day solve hard scientific or mathematical problems, but mathematicians are more cautious because details of the models’ results and how they work haven’t been made public.

Advertisement

The IMO, one of the world’s most prestigious competitions for young mathematicians, has long been seen by AI researchers as a litmus test for mathematical reasoning that AI systems tend to struggle with.

After last year’s competition held in Bath, UK, Google DeepMindannounced that AI systems it had developed, called AlphaProof and AlphaGeometry, had together achieved a silver medal-level performance, but its entries weren’t graded by the competition’s official markers.

Before this year’s contest, which was held in Queensland, Australia, companies including Google, Huawei and TikTok-owner ByteDance, as well as academic researchers, approached the organisers to ask whether they could have their AI models’ performance officially graded, says Gregor Dolinar, the IMO’s president. The IMO agreed, with the proviso that the companies waited to announce their results until 28 July, when the IMO’s full closing ceremonies had been completed.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Daily The latest on what’s new in science and why it matters each day. Sign up to newsletter

OpenAI also asked if it could participate in the competition, but after it was informed about the official scheme, it didn’t respond or register an entry, says Dolinar.

On 19 July, OpenAI announced that a new AI it had developed had achieved a gold medal score marked by three former IMO medallists separate from the official competition. The AI answered five out of six questions correctly in the same 4.5-hour time limit as the contestants, OpenAI said.

Two days later, Google DeepMind also announced that its AI system, called Gemini Deep Think, had achieved gold with the same score and time limits. Dolinar confirmed that this result was given by the IMO’s official markers.

Unlike Google’s AlphaProof and AlphaGeometry systems, which were crafted especially for the competition and worked with questions and answers written in a computer programming language called Lean, both Google and OpenAI’s models this year worked entirely in natural language.

Working in Lean meant the AI’s output could be instantly checked for correctness, but it is harder for non-experts to read. Thang Luong at Google, who worked on Gemini Deep Think, says the natural language approach could produce more understandable answers, as well as being applicable to generally useful AI systems.

Luong says the ability to verify solutions in a large language model has been made possible thanks to progress with reinforcement learning, a training method in which an AI is taught what success looks like and is left to figure out the rules and how to succeed solely through trial and error. This method was key to Google’s previous success with its game-playing AIs, such as AlphaZero.

Google’s model also considers multiple solutions at once, in a mode called parallel thinking, as well as being trained on a dataset of maths problems specifically useful for the IMO, says Luong.

OpenAI has released few details on its system, apart from that it also uses reinforcement learning and “experimental research methods”.

“The progress is promising, but not performed in a controlled scientific fashion, and so I will not be able to assess it at this stage,” says Terence Tao at the University of California, Los Angeles. “Perhaps once the companies involved release some papers with more data, and hopefully enough access to the model for others to replicate the results, one can say something more definitive, but, for now, we largely have to trust the companies themselves for the claimed results.”

Geordie Williamson at the University of Sydney in Australia agrees. “I think it is remarkable that this is where we’re at. It is frustrating how little detail outsiders are provided with regarding internals,” says Williamson.

While systems working in natural language could be useful for non-mathematicians, it could also present a problem if models produce long proofs that are hard to check, says Joseph Myers, one of the organisers of this year’s IMO. “If AIs are ever to produce solutions to significant unsolved problems that might plausibly be correct but might also have a few subtle but fatal errors hidden accidentally, or potentially deliberately from a misaligned AI, having those AIs also generate a formal proof is key to having confidence in the correctness of a long AI output before attempting to read it.”

Both companies say that, in the coming months, they will offer these systems for testing to mathematicians at first, before releasing them to the wider public. The models could soon help with harder scientific research problems, says Junehyuk Jung at Google, who worked on Gemini Deep Think. “There are going to be many, many unsolved problems within reach,” he says.
articles.reasoning: The achievement of AI models reaching gold medal standards in a prestigious math competition represents a significant scientific and technological breakthrough. It showcases progress in AI capabilities that could lead to solving complex scientific problems, inspiring hope for future advancements.
articles.personality_title: AI wins gold in top math contest, breaking new ground
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) is a highly respected contest where young math talents from around the world solve tricky problems. Until now, no artificial intelligence (AI) had reached the gold medal standard in this challenging competition.

**What happened**
Two AI models, one from Google’s DeepMind and another from OpenAI, have for the first time achieved gold-level results at the IMO. This means these AIs solved math problems at the same level as the best young human mathematicians.

**Impact**
This breakthrough shows AI is getting much better at understanding and solving complex math questions. Since math is the foundation of many scientific problems, these advances could help tackle tough challenges in science and technology, speeding up discoveries.

**What’s next step**
Researchers plan to keep improving AI’s reasoning and problem-solving skills. The goal is to apply this advanced math ability to real-world scientific questions, potentially making big leaps in fields like physics, biology, and engineering.

**One-sentence takeaway**
AI has just earned a gold medal in a top math contest, opening new doors for solving science’s hardest puzzles.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'IA décroche l'or dans un grand concours de maths, une première
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
L'Olympiade internationale de mathématiques (IMO) est un concours très réputé où de jeunes talents du monde entier résolvent des problèmes complexes. Jusqu'à présent, aucune intelligence artificielle (IA) n'avait atteint le niveau de médaille d'or dans cette compétition exigeante.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Deux modèles d'IA, un de Google DeepMind et un autre d'OpenAI, ont pour la première fois obtenu des résultats de niveau or à l'IMO. Cela signifie que ces IA ont résolu des problèmes mathématiques au même niveau que les meilleurs jeunes mathématiciens.

**Impact**
Cette avancée montre que l'IA progresse beaucoup dans la compréhension et la résolution de problèmes mathématiques complexes. Comme les mathématiques sont la base de nombreux problèmes scientifiques, ces progrès pourraient aider à relever de grands défis en sciences et technologies, accélérant les découvertes.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à améliorer les capacités de raisonnement et de résolution de problèmes des IA. L'objectif est d'appliquer cette compétence mathématique avancée à des questions scientifiques concrètes, pour faire des bonds en avant dans des domaines comme la physique, la biologie et l'ingénierie.

**En une phrase**
L'IA a remporté une médaille d'or dans un grand concours de maths, ouvrant la voie à la résolution des énigmes scientifiques les plus difficiles.
articles.personality_title_es: La IA gana oro en concurso de matemáticas, marcando un nuevo hito
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La Olimpiada Internacional de Matemáticas (IMO) es una competencia muy respetada donde jóvenes talentos de todo el mundo resuelven problemas difíciles. Hasta ahora, ninguna inteligencia artificial (IA) había alcanzado el nivel de medalla de oro en esta exigente competición.

**Qué pasó**
Dos modelos de IA, uno de Google DeepMind y otro de OpenAI, lograron por primera vez resultados de nivel oro en la IMO. Esto significa que estas IA resolvieron problemas matemáticos al mismo nivel que los mejores jóvenes matemáticos.

**Impacto**
Este avance muestra que la IA está mejorando mucho en entender y resolver problemas matemáticos complejos. Como las matemáticas son la base de muchos problemas científicos, estos avances podrían ayudar a enfrentar grandes retos en ciencia y tecnología, acelerando los descubrimientos.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean seguir mejorando las habilidades de razonamiento y resolución de problemas de la IA. La meta es aplicar esta habilidad matemática avanzada a preguntas científicas reales, haciendo grandes avances en campos como la física, biología e ingeniería.

**Frase clave**
La IA acaba de ganar una medalla de oro en un importante concurso de matemáticas, abriendo nuevas puertas para resolver los retos científicos más difíciles.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of two glowing, intricately designed golden medals floating above an open ancient scroll filled with elegant mathematical symbols and geometric shapes, set against a soft background of softly glowing puzzle pieces interlocking seamlessly, all rendered in gentle natural tones of gold, cream, and muted blues, symbolizing AI achievement and breakthrough in advanced mathematical problem-solving.
